awd_titl_txt: Workshop:  2017 NSF Proposal Writing Workshop; Los Angeles, California; June 4, 2017
awd_abstract_narration:
An NSF proposal writing workshop will be held on June 4, 2017, at the University of Southern California. The workshop will be collocated with the 45th SME North American Manufacturing Research Conference (NAMRC) and the ASME Manufacturing Science and Engineering Conference (MSEC 2017). The workshop aims to aid future NSF proposal submitters in communicating clear research objectives and improving proposal quality. Interactions during the workshop will help build meaningful collaborations. This will positively affect the attendees, academic career and, subsequently, will help develop the nation's human resources. Additionally, when proposals are well written, the reviews tend to be more consistent and NSF panel meetings are more efficient.

Major activities of the workshop include: presentations by NSF program directors, breakout sessions to discuss example research objectives, a group question/answer period, and a conclusions session. Professors and graduate students from across the US will be invited to attend the workshop. Participants will learn guidelines for writing a quality NSF proposal with an emphasis on the research objective.

por.por_cntn:
An NSF proposal writing workshop was held on June 4, 2017, at the University of Southern California. The workshop was collocated with the 45th SME North American Manufacturing Research Conference (NAMRC) and the ASME Manufacturing Science and Engineering Conference (MSEC 2017). The workshop aimed to aid future NSF proposal submitters in communicating clear research objectives and improving proposal quality. This workshop built on the success of the 2015 and 2016 NSF proposal writing workshop held in Charlotte, NC and Blacksburg, VA.

Intellectual merit

Major activities of the workshop included:

  • presentations by George Hazelrigg, Steve Schmid, and Tony Schmitz
  • individual activities to practice defining a research objective
  • group activity to discuss example proposal summaries
  • question/answer period with NSF personnel.

Broader impacts

Professors and graduate students from both the US and other countries attended the workshop. They learned guidelines for writing a quality research objective. Interactions during the workshop with colleagues helped foster meaningful collaborations. The relationships developed during the workshop will positively affect the attendees’ academic careers and, subsequently, will help develop the nation’s human resources. Additionally, by improving the participants’ proposals, the panel reviews will be more consistent. This will help in making the NSF panel review meetings run more smoothly.
